misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem instead of the grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a distance-between-two-points calculator instead of a grade-to-letter-grade converter. They read four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2), compute a Euclidean distance, and print that result, rather than reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade with conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates of two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade (0–100) from the user and then use conditional statements to map that numeric grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges, then print the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
Uses four double variables (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a numeric grade variable.
Computes a distance using the square root of squared differences, not any grade-based logic.
No conditional (if/else) statements for grade ranges are present.
Output message describes distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely reusing or recalling a distance-formula exercise instead of carefully implementing the specified grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem specification carefully and list the required inputs, processing steps, and outputs before coding. For this task, you should: (1) read one numeric grade from input, (2) use if/else-if conditions to check which range it belongs to (90–100, 80–89, etc.), and (3) print the corresponding letter grade exactly as requested.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program, including variable names, prompts, formula, and output, matches a distance-formula problem and does not implement any aspect of the requested grade calculator.

evidence.note: Prompts, variables, and computation all correspond to a distance-between-two-points problem, not reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), which is completely unrelated to the required task of creating a grade calculator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe the assignment was about calculating the distance between two points, perhaps confusing this problem with another assignment or template code.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
Program attempts to read four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one (grade).
Uses the distance formula (Math.sqrt, etc.) instead of conditional branching.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements (Q3 Grade Calculator) or the use of existing boilerplate code from a different task (distance formula).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement for Q3: Grade Calculator. You need to read a single integer/double for the grade and use if-else statements to assign a letter grade based on the given ranges (90-100 is A, 80-89 is B, etc.).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is an implementation of the distance formula between two points, confirmed by the variable names (x1, y1, x2, y2) and the calculation (Math.sqrt((x2-x1)...)). This directly fails to address the Grade Calculator requirement.

evidence.note: The code implements a distance calculator, not the requested grade calculator. It reads four inputs and uses the distance formula.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Program Submitted - Distance Calculator Instead of Grade Calculator
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a completely different program (distance calculator between two points) instead of the required grade calculator program. This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or submission of wrong code.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should submit a program to calculate the distance between two points using the formula sqrt((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²)
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), F (below 60).
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates distance instead of determining letter grade
Output shows distance calculation result, not letter grade
None of the rubric categories can be satisfied by this code
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different assignment or problem. This could stem from copy-pasting wrong code, confusion about assignment requirements, or working on multiple assignments simultaneously.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The program should: (1) prompt for a single numeric grade (0-100), (2) use if-else statements with appropriate Boolean conditions to check ranges, (3) output the corresponding letter grade A, B, C, D, or F based on the scale provided.
related_concepts: Input validation and reading user input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code is for a completely different problem (calculating Euclidean distance) with no relation to grade calculation. The input prompts, variables, calculations, and output are all unrelated to the grade calculator specification.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates Euclidean distance between two points, which is completely different from the required grade calculator task.

misconceptions.name: Implemented completely different problem (distance calculator instead of grade calculator)

The input, processing, and output are all for a different task, so none of the rubric requirements (reading a single grade, using conditionals for ranges, mapping to A–F) are addressed.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine which range it falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinate pairs instead of a single grade value.
Program uses double variables x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade variable.
No conditional statements or range checks for A/B/C/D/F are present.
Output describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or reuse of code from a different assignment (distance formula) instead of implementing the specified grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Start a new program that reads exactly one numeric grade (0–100) from the user and then uses if/else-if/else to check which grade range it falls into and prints the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F). Ignore any previous distance-formula code.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric values to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, variables, computation, and output) is aligned with a distance formula problem and not at all with a grade-to-letter-grade mapping problem.

evidence.note: The code reads coordinate pairs, computes a distance, and prints a distance message, which does not match the required behavior of reading a single grade and printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student completely misunderstood the assignment. Instead of reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and determining its letter grade, the student wrote a program to read two coordinate pairs and calculate the Euclidean distance between them. This is a fundamentally different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a distance calculator program for two points in 2D space.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade value (0-100) and using conditional logic to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
Code uses distance formula instead of grade range logic
No conditional statements for grade ranges
Output is distance between points, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read the wrong problem statement, misread the assignment instructions, or submitted code from a different assignment entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. You need to: (1) Read ONE numeric grade input, (2) Use if-else statements to check if the grade falls into each range (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60), (3) Output the corresponding letter grade. Start over with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculator) rather than the assigned problem (grade calculator). There is no overlap in functionality, inputs, or expected outputs.

evidence.note: Student reads coordinates instead of a single grade value

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Student calculates and outputs distance formula, not grade logic
